title: Question 22

children: An 81-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for confusion, fever, and shaking chills overnight. He has had increasing difficulty in fully emptying his bladder, urinary frequency, and dysuria for the past 3 days. He received a 7-day course of ciprofloxacin 1 month ago for cystitis with documented pyuria and bacteriuria. Medical history is also significant for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

On physical examination, he is disoriented to the date. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102 °F), blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 102/min, and respiration rate is 20/min. The bladder is distended, but no costovertebral angle tenderness is elicited.
A dipstick urinalysis shows 2+ blood; 3+ nitrites; and 3+ leukocyte esterase.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intravenous treatment?

Reasonable initial antibiotic choices for severely ill patients with acute prostatitis include an intravenous broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotic, such as an extended-spectrum penicillin or cephalosporin, with or without the addition of an aminoglycoside.

Fluoroquinolones should not be used as initial antibiotic therapy in patients with severe infection that warrants hospitalization when local resistance rates exceed 10% or when other patient-specific resistance risk factors (e.g., recent hospitalization or fluoroquinolone use) exist.

Secondary bacteremia occurs in about 25% of patients with acute prostatitis and is the most common cause of bacteremia in older men.
